reviewText: I got this Blu-ray today as a Father's day present.  This is better than I could expect, and for those who complain of audio issues, I don't see how.  I have two different surround systems in my house and have already tried this disc on both and have no issues.  The BASS IS VERY MUCH THERE thumping and pumping.  The picture is great and if you compare it to other concert videos from that era, it is as good (i.e. Led Zeppelin "The Song Remains the Same, The Who Kilburn to mention a couple of BR discs that I've watched multiple times) as those.  I have very sensitive ears to bad audio and it wasn't there.  So if you're sitting on the fence on this one, take my advice and get it.  This is one of the best concert videos you could own; a must have for Beatles/McCartney fans.
summary: Sitting in the Stands of the Sports arena

reviewText: Truth be known, this was Wings at their peak.  What can you say about a show that begins with the simple, acoustic "Venus & Mars" which segues perfectly into "Rock Show?"  GREAT lyrics, "Rock 'n roll @ the Hollywood Bowl, long hair @ Madison Square," and something @ the "Concertgebow," which is a theatrical something in Holland. Jimmy McCullough SHINES on guitar, infinitely preferable to his predecessor and, uh...the guy who followed him.  His "Medicine Jar" is the absolute-est ROCK AND ROLL number of the entire set!  Damn shame that later the poor guy went out the way he preached against in the song.  Linda is lovely, very quiet; indeed, most of her keyboard parts are taken over by Denny Laine (whose performance on his own "Time To Hide," toward the end of the set will actually let you forgive the man for once having been a member of the limp-wristed Moody Blues).  And my Homeboy, Joe English plays...no, POUNDS like a disciple of Keith Moon.  You get no better (McCartney obviously wasn't looking for a Charlie Watts).  But sad to say, I have seen and heard this performance - but I have the boot of the concert that DIDN'T "feature" (ugh) "The Long & Winding Road."  I don't think I'd be too excited about the advertised "lovely little party," but, yeah, I'm gonna get this when it comes out, if only to hear Paul Rock And Roll in 5.1 - especially "Letting Go!"
summary: I've Just Seen A similar DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: We first got a taste of Rockshow on DVD when a few selections from it were included onThe McCartney Yearscollection. Those little selections were pretty unsatisfying and I wondered if it might be an indication that Rockshow just doesn't stand up to modern concert films. Seeing the whole thing, I realise how wrong I was about that.It's not that Rockshow is without its flaws. Indeed, it's defined by them. The camera angles are either off to the side, looking down from a distance or pointing right up the band's noses. These angles are sometimes blocked by mic stands, miss bits and are frequently out of focus.In other words, it's just like being there.In the newly recorded introduction to the film, Paul claims that Wings started from nothing. This is true, if by "nothing," you mean having only one ex-Beatle and an ex-Moody Blue. Still, something that defined Wings was a habit of dropping themselves into a situation without a plan - from an ad-hoc tour of any uni bar that would have them, to deciding to record Band on the Run in a half-built studio in Nigeria (what could possibly go wrong?) - and muddling through thanks to a combination of enthusiasm, showmanship and a musical talent that people would kill just to have just one tenth of. Rockshow is really no different. It was filmed over several nights at the end of the 1976 Wings Over America tour with seemingly no provision made for the filming or for continuity. At one point, Denny Laine manages to turn a black Precision Bass into a Blonde Telecaster bass, and Jimmy McCulloch changes it back a few songs later. There are a couple of other points where Jimmy's fingers are clearly playing different licks to the ones being heard.What is really interesting about the set list is that although they were promoting the Wings at the Speed of Sound album at the time, it's the previous album, Venus and Mars that is drawn on the most heavily. It actually came as a surprise to me when they played Band on the Run near the end of the set because I really hadn't missed it. Naturally, the few Beatles songs that are dropped into the set draw huge cheers but the show is by no means built around them. Wings had no need to lean on the Beatles connection at this point, but Macca has always been a crowd-pleaser and knew that people would want at least a couple of Beatles numbers.  Also, there's a real, live, 4-piece horn section. Remember how good that sounded, Paul?The new 5.1 mix is restrained, with the surround channels being used only for audience noise. I usually consider this a pretty lazy use of a surround mix but in this case, along with the photography, it complements the simulation of the concert experience.  The rest of the mix is a traditional rock and roll arrangement with guitars left and right, as it should be.Of course, there's plenty of 70s dagginess included as well. Mullets abound and Paul looks for all the world like he is wearing pyjama pants. Despite its flaws - indeed, probably because of them - Rockshow really is the perfect record of Wings at the height of their powers in what was a pretty high-tech show in its day.

reviewText: I went to go see McCarney and Wings on May 29, 1976 in Kansas City, Missouri.  I have seen Elvis, Chuck Berry, first row Marvin Gaye, first row Grateful Dead...etc....nothing prior or since has ever surpassed this show, and I have seen McCartney many times since that first time.  I have put off buying the latest round of McCartney items, as I have so many prior issues, deluxe issues, originals, etc, but I do look forward to the release of Rockshow done right, as all I had prior to this were my memories and some rough bootlegs obtained in the late 1970's early 80's, and was always frustrated as to why there were not high quality releases.  I look forward to Wing's Over America deluxe release as well.  It is just unbelievable that it is just several years short of four decades.  It will be a fun summer of viewing and listening to all of this over again, and am equally thankful that it is a lengthy version as well.

reviewText: Rock-show is a treat, not only for us fans of Paul the Solo act, but a vindication of a master showman who had to start all over like in his hamburg days, touring colleges, having to work on a budget, remember, his money was tied up in the whole Sue Me Sue You drama of Apple and Allen Klein and unfortunately his exbandmates, so at the early stages he did not have money to pull out of the bank really to finance anything fancy and his early albums, McCartney,Ram, and then Wings Wild Life, Red-rose Speedway, which weren't exactly platinum records. Then came Band on the Run and after that Venus and Mars. The creative juices were overflowing.Paul McCartney was back with a vengeance. He was ready to take on the world and this film is a great time capsule of Paul finally standing tall again. He was having a better time then the rest of us it appears. The picture captures the sparkle of someone who worked hard not to end up a has been putting out mediocre music and living off the name of a band long gone. The whole film is one big musical smile for us and Paul as a unit. After this, no McCartney concert would tour with any vacant unsold seats. This film is important because it is a taped witness of the Paul whose life was clouded by hurt friendships, contested monies, taxes, was gone and there on stage was not the Ex Beatle Bassist but Paul the musician par excellence , the man who should have opened every tour after that with "Good Day Sunshine", an apt song to reflect the Sunshine Paul exuded once again after so many years of melodrama. Those who remember the bad old days of the post Let It Be era like myself really were rooting for Paul at the tour and once again watching this film.
summary: Paul out of the Beatles shadow-And this film proves it.

reviewText: Yes the audio is not by 2013 standards and the visual might seem grainy for some, but the performances themselves are undeniable. I have absolutely no complaints for this DVD, its quality or its contents. We should be lucky this DVD got any attention for release at all since many of the time treasured rock and roll films and music remain vaulted and forgotten over the years, Frank Zappa and The Rolling Stones R&R Circus come to mind! What I see in "Rockshow" is the enthusiasm and energy McCartney & Wings displayed during the Wings Over America tours of 1975-76. Most critics miss the point here. They see everything through a Beatles lens, which includes the scrutiny of wife Linda, whom in my opinion, seems closer to being musician than ornament and annoying screamer Yoko Ono. Secondly, Denny Laine takes charge on vocals, guitar, keyboards and snare per "Let 'Em In" as well as the Moody Blues hit, "Go Now". Guitarist Jimmy McCulloch also chimes in on vocals and exacts some signature guitar solos and the horn section does a great job. People tend to view everything through a "high tech" digital view because they've been spoiled by todays films and music. I for one, enjoy the old school technology as I appreciate artists and music of the past more than the plastic, untalented and manufactured artists today that won't go near a guitar, drums or piano. McCartney had the hardest job of all post Beatles because he simply continued to write, perform and tour under some harsh circumstances of the time. I don't believe as rock and roll fans we appreciated, encouraged, supported or deserve anything from Sir Paul. To purchase this DVD with the price I paid and watching Paul McCartney being happy after what he'd been through in those years, I'd say we owe McCartney a lot more than an apology. I recommend this DVD absolutely for anyone!

reviewText: This Blu ray brought back floods of memories for me. I remember having this concert on third generation VHS tape, and the quality was fair at best, but the music was still wonderful. Now, finally after years of waiting it has been re-mastered and the memories just fondly rushed back.Technically, the video is crisp, and the audio is superb, even the occasional times when the camera pans the audience, I'm sure many of you will have fond memories of the mid-to-late seventies attire we all used to wear.In closing, this disc brought me back to a time when I first discovered how great music really could be.It was also wonderful to see the late Linda McCartney performing with the band during its' highest peak - she truly is missed.This disc is a keeper, and a must have !

reviewText: * UPDATE - November 7, 2013 - I am glad that I WAITED until after October 6, 2013 to "re-purchase" this release DIRECTLY from Amazon.* Yesterday I spent almost four hours watching and re-watching "Rockshow," checking and re-checking everything.  Cut to the chase - everything now sounds awesome.  The bass drops and audio phase "echo chambering" aggravations are gone.  All of the sound mastering errors scattered across the first consumer release of this product in June 2013 - have been FIXED.* The odd thing - which is EXPECTED - is the audio on "Rockshow" is now BETTER than the video, in both Blu-ray and DVD formats.  The reasons why this is so - have already been covered by previous reviewers.  Simply put, the original negative used to digitally re-master "Rockshow" - was high speed color film stock shot during the Wings Over America tour in May and June of 1976.  As a result, this footage is purposely very grainy in dark areas of the frame - and the primitive spotlighting effects used at live concerts during the 1970s gives "Rockshow" a mostly red-orange-pinkish color cast - which tends to wash out details you normally see in movies that are shot today with high definition cameras.* This is, in my view, how it should be.  I hate when vintage films are morphed into things that look like "Avatar."  When older films are re-mastered, I want dirt and debris removed, but I don't want "kids armed with computer toys" to over-enhance the original colors and contrast that audiences saw in theaters when they were first projected brightly onto a big screen.* Meanwhile, I had forgotten that Wings - that is, the band that performed on stage - was, in some ways, modeled like the Beatles in that its major players like Denny Laine ("Go Now") and Jimmy McCulloch ("Medicine Jar") were given vocal solos, e.g., like how George Harrison and Ringo Starr got to sing at every Beatles concert despite being in the shadow of Lennon and McCartney.  Some songs on "Rockshow" have not aged very well, e.g., if you never liked the lyrics to "Silly Love Songs," your opinion won't change today, even though that song still boasts a kick-ass bass line performed by Paul.  But other songs, such as "Picasso's Last Words (Drink to Me)" - sound better performed live in "Rockshow" - than what was recorded in a studio.* Keep video quality expectations realistic and you'll love "Rockshow."  It was Wings at their peak - when McCartney was still a titanic force in the music industry, racking up a string of #1 hits, selling millions of records and tapes after the Beatles broke up.  Now in his 70s, McCartney is a genius who's no longer a prolific #1 hitmaker - but who can still sell out stadiums around the world.  Even if you don't like ALL of the songs on "Rockshow," it remains an important historical record of Paul as he was at age 34, still vigorously energetic with a monster voice.  That's why it's in my library.(ORIGINAL PRODUCT NOTES THAT WERE POSTED EARLIER THIS YEAR ARE BELOW.)===========================================* For what it's worth, perhaps because of the avalanche of complaints about audio problems associated with both the Blu-ray and standard issue DVDs of "Rockshow," Eagle Rock Entertainment has just updated its website.* Eagle Rock now says "Rockshow" - which was first released on June 11, 2013 - will have an official "re-release" (though it refuses to call it a re-release) - on Blu-ray and DVD on October 6, 2013.* You can check this out yourself by going to the Eagle Rock Entertainment site and enter the words, "Rockshow Wings Over America" into Eagle Rock's search engine.* Note that the new October 6 re-release date for "Rockshow" falls on a Sunday, which is a freakish thing in relation to most DVDs being issued on Tuesdays.  Nevertheless, this is the information that appears on the manufacturer's website.* By October 6, 2013, I anticipate the "mixing" of defective vs. corrected discs in Amazon's inventory will have been purged en masse, to be replaced by corrected products in both Blu-ray and DVD formats.* It's not quite a "recall" because you still have to be "proactive" if you purchased "Rockshow" before October 6 and find yourself stuck with a defective disc, but to me, the manufacturer's "new release date" is VERY telling.
summary: "Rockshow" Fixed, Gets "Second Release" in Four Months and Now Sounds Awesome

reviewText: OK, I admit it, I was a huge Wings fan in the 70's and 80's.  It seems like every Summer the band had a top ten single (at least one, maybe two) and you heard them on the radio all the time.  Sometimes a little too much!Some people don't want to admit that Paul was ever in another band besides that other group he was in from Liverpool.  I think they remember the fab four and then fast forward to the great solo bands he's had in the last two decades.  If you've been fortunate enough to see him in recent years you know he puts on a great show and has top notch musicians.But this was filmed in the days when Paul really wanted a 'band', not just a backing group.  And this is really a band here.  Lots of material from "Band On The Run", "Venus And Mars" and "At The Speed of Sound" featuring a BAND that isn't merely backing up the future 'Sir' Paul.  Indeed, a lot of the tracks I'm digging on this are sung by Denny Laine, such as "Picasso's Last Words" and "Time To Hide". Jimmy McCullogh's guitar playing is just awesome, it's a real tragedy he died so young, but this video is a great testimony to his talent.So, as the typical Wings album had a mix of styles, you get that here, too.  Acoustic numbers, ballads, slow R&B; grooves, music hall style tunes, and out and out rockers.  If you like Wings, and remember all those great albums fondly, you will love this.  If you are undecided about Wings and how it fits into Paul's career, you need to watch this.  It's a great band, playing tight and having a blast on stage!I own the Blu-ray and I have no technical issues.

reviewText: Sorry-why is the DVD version of this almost as much as the BLU-RAY version? Why would you spend 26.99 when Blu-ray is about same price....I guess they dont want you buying regular DVD. But this concert doesn't have much visually that warrants buying Blu-ray. No special effects (this isnt a Pink Floyd laser concert)We finally get the full concert that has been available as a bootleg for many years  but not on VHS or laserdisc. The six missing songs (Picasso/Richard Cory. Long and winding road/Lady Madonna, and for Japanese fans Blackbird and Yesterday were omitted, Hopefully the missing songs will be of equal quality to the rest of the concert. Why they omitted those six songs and NOT include Lady Madonna or Long and Winding Road in its original release remains a mystery) There isnt much bonus material  for 26.99. The Beach Boys just released a concert DvD 11.99.  Neil Young Just released a new concert "Journeys" 14.99, At 26.99 this is pricey.  The Eagles History is 24.99 but you get THREE Discs!  SO for this price  I'll stick to the 24.99 Blu-ray as this DVD regular version isnt worth 26.99. Should be no more than 16.99 for a regular single disc concert.

reviewText: I attended the Madison Square Garden show of the Wings Over America tour in 1976, and have waited a very long time for this to come out in it's entirety.  The show is awesome - the problem was, I had to buy 4 different copies before I got one without manufacturing defects.  The first two had bass drop-outs in the audio track (well documented in many user forums on the internet).  The 3rd copy would get to a certain point on the disc and just freeze; FINALLY, the fourth copy was free of defects.  Amazon was great in providing an easy return policy; however, I wrote several times to Eagle Rock asking for help, and never even got a response, much less any help.  Sir Paul needs to work with a better quality outfit when putting out his product.
summary: Excellent concert; AWFUL quality control and customer service by Eagle Rock.

I am reviewing the product and it deserves zero stars for the audio issues. The performance, and when the sound is "on" is 5 star. I will remove and replace with a five star review when the full recall commences.* Replacement disc received from Eagle Rock(July 26th) is perfect. With the issue addressed, this concert is certainly a five star product. Not sure about Amazon stock though.

reviewText: Due to Eagle Rock's acknowledgment of the Audio low frequency dropout's and according to users who contacted Eagle Rock they claim they will release a new fixed version. I am wondering If they will in fact significantly improve or fix the problem.I hope there will be in the upcoming fixed version be a way to distinguish it from the defective.I Personally would wait a year so hopefully all the old stock is gone from new sales. Hard to know if Amazon will fully get rid of the defective ones or mix them in and continue selling them till they sell all of them and just have the fixed versions.Concerning Picture quality... The orig VHS/Laserdisc versions have much more top and bottom picture in the frame. However the DVD/Blue discs have equally more picture on the sides than the VHS/Laserdisc. An example of the cropping on Silly Love Songs When the Brass section is first shown behind Paul.. the DVD/Blu versions totally have cropped the brass members heads out of the picture frame whereas the VHS/Laserdisc vers. you see their entire faces and top of their heads.The Color, sharpness and overall picture quality is far superior on the DVD/Bluray.Either way there is a trade off.... wish they would use the actual aspect ratio the movie was filmed and framed rather than cropping it to fit a 16x9 television - so that nothing would be cropped.
summary: Hope Audio Problems get Fixed - DVD/BlueRay Cropped Pic

reviewText: IF YOU HAVEN'T PICKED UP THE NEW REMASTERED VERSION OF "ROCKSHOW" YET RUN DON'T WALK TO YOUR NEAREST STORE OR COMPUTER AND GET IT NOW. THE TRANSFER IS ABSOLUTELY FAN-DAMN-TASTIC AS IS THENEWLY REMIXED AUDIO. THIS IS WITHOUT A DOUBT THE GREATEST CONCERT FILM OF ALL TIME AND WE FINALLYGET TO SEE IT IN IT'S ENTIRETY WITH NO INTERRUPTIONS FROM BEGINNING TO END. BY THE TIME I FINISHED WATCHING IT I FELT LIKE I HAD BEEN THERE! THIS IS ANY MCCARTNEY FAN'S DREAM COME TRUE. THE PACKAGING IS TOP NOTCH TOO. THE DVD COMES HOUSED IN A HARD COVER GLOSSY BOOK WITH A THICK BOOKLET INSIDE WITH LOTS OF PHOTOS AND GOOD TEXT. THE DVD ALSO HAS A BONUS FEATURE ENTITLED "A VERY LOVELY PARTY" WHICH IS TEN MINUTES OF COOL BACKSTAGE FOOTAGE FEATURING RINGO AND THE LATE GREAT HARRY NILSSON AMONG OTHER CELEBRITIES. THIS PACKAGE MAKES UP FOR THE RATHER THIN "WINGS OVER AMERICA" CD REMASTER. I HAD FORGOTTEN THAT "ROCKSHOW" HAS DIFFERENT PERFORMANCES THAN THE ONE'S HEARDON THE "WINGS OVER AMERICA" ALBUM. THEY SHOULD HAVE USED THE ONES IN THE FILM ON THE CD'S. ALLIN ALL A FANTASTIC RELEASE. DON'T MISS IT. AS PAUL SAY'S; "FANCY A BIT OF ROCK & ROLL?"
summary: PAUL IS AMAZING, NO MAYBE ABOUT IT!

reviewText: I'm amazed at the huge difference of opinions on the qualify of this blu ray disc.  My son bought this for me from Amazon for Father's Day as he knows how much my wife and I love the Beatles, Wings, and Paul specifically.I thought the packaging was very nice with the built in booklet.The disc itself was viewed with great anticipation ignoring other reviewers comments and seeing for ourselves.First, I have very good equipment from the amp to the speakers and sub.  I have a lot a great music discs that sound wonderful and look great.Understand, I am aware of this being an older concert, but other old concerts like the Stones at the Max look and sound great.My Samsung Plasma has never crapped out during dark or black scenes of movies.From the very first note of this concert, I was aware that the naysayers were right.  This is a  mostly very grainy slightly out of focus presentation throughout.  The grain seemed to dissipate in some of the brighter scenes, but there was never a pristine picture.The sound was played as DTS 5.1.  It also was not very good. It sounded very old tech and very disappointing.  I don't care how good your equipment is, this is not a good presentation.  I didn't see inconsistency like others did.  I thought is was consistently poor quality throughout.

reviewText: OK, I'd give a 5 just for the audio, but it was so disconcerting to see mouths not match in sync with the words, especially Joe English on the drums.  He's so adept and really gives it his all, but it was like seeing a band across the football field in reverse:  I'd see the bass drummer hit a lick, then I'd hear the sound as he raised his hand; in the video, I'd hear the sound, then see the hand strike.  Very disconcerting.Most of the vocals were in sync, but I'd see some delay occasionally.Audio?  Perfect!Anyone else think that Jimmy looked like a young George (at times) and Denny like John Lennon.  OK, Joe's left handed (but so is Ringo by the way).  Anyone else think the tempos on the songs were slower than what we buy?  Some seemed to almost drag.  Did the DJs play them faster to get more songs in?  don't know.Wonderful to see McCartney in not-long-after-the-Beatles form.  He could really hit those high notes, and he looks to really be having a great time.Anyway, that's my assessment.  Minus one star for the sync factor, but I'd love to just turn this on and turn off the TV!
Title: N/A

reviewText: After owning this masterpiece of a performance on bootleg dvd-r for countless years, I am truly delighted at this official version, soon to be released.This 1976 concert film is one of the few "proper" concert releases from Paul.  No annoying, overly done crowd scenes.  No jumpy editing.  No backstage footage or other irritating deterrents that distract the fans from the main performance.  This is a straight-up, no-nonsense, well-filmed concert video.  And, to my knowledge, it is the only complete Wings performance that has seen official release to date.The setlist features some songs that remain in Paul's repertoire for concerts today ("Band On The Run," "Jet"), but it also features some more obscure tracks like "Venus And Mars," "Rock Show" "Hi Hi Hi" and others of that sort.This film is a good document of Paul and Wings, and I am excited to finally have it coming on DVD.

reviewText: I've had this concert dubbed from LaserDisc for twenty years or better.  Now, I have the version I always hoped for.  This is post Beatles McCartney finding his footing as an individual.  Funny, it took a real band for Macca to really shine however.  And what a great band this 1.5 version of Wings is.  It is the definitive version and this concert states a clear case for that.  Denny Laine was the right second banana to Macca.  He had the chops and knew to stay in the right place for most of his run.  Here he may have had a little chemical tuning, but he's on and he adds a lot.  So does Jimmy McCulloch.  Medicine Jar will become sadly poignant in just a few years.  Then the big man on the skins.  Joe English looks like he is waging a battle whereby the trap set has submitted to him "lording" over it with vigorous corrections if it threatens to get out of line (LOL!).  Seriously, English was a great hard hitter with decent finesse shown on the cymbal and other percussive work.  And, I'll make a case for Linda.  When I was younger I will admit I wondered why Paul was so attracted to Linda, after all he could have almost any woman.  Well, Linda was his soul-mate first, but what that entailed was really cool.  She shared the most important thing in his life which would be his music and their children.  She was totally "hands-on" singing and playing the keys.  In fact, she did better on the keys than I ever realized because Wickens, today with his advanced pre-programmed MIDI segments et.all, just equals Linda's keyboard sound.  Wickens really doesn't eclipse anything Linda is doing here in the seventies.  That's pretty much a big "hell yeah" for Linda.  I know she took a lot of kidding, some really mean-spirited, for her singing, but you can hear her and she definitely adds more than any possible detraction so I just wish the "haters" who like to tear her apart vocally would just go listen to some awful Velvet Underground drivel (an overrated band that rightly didn't appeal to many then or now).  Sorry, I got side-tracked.  Anyway, I love this incarnation of Wings and proclaim it to be the definitive and only version that matters.The picture is soft like film of the era and I don't mean this in a bad way.  Nope, there's detail even in the low-light film with grain.  The best re-mastering has likely been done for the visuals and since it's spades ahead of my old DVD of a dub from laserdisc I'm more than overjoyed.  The sound is really amped up and gorgeous.  Could it be better?  Some have speculated so, but I think they're nuts as the sound is fantastic and holds up when played at crazy loud levels through Klipsch speakers.This is my favorite all-time concert on video.  Thanks Paul for putting it out.  I know you don't need the money so I am grateful as a fan that you respect us enough to make loads of video available.  Anything you put out we'll likely buy, but when it is as good as this it somehow feels like a great gift dropped down from somewhere and suddenly there were smiles everywhere.  Yep, your music has always had that uncanny effect on me since I was old enough to draw pictures of four stick figures with some cool boxes on stage that said VOX.  This is a must buy concert if you love good rock and roll music because it rarely, if ever, has been done better.

reviewText: I saw the group in May 1976 at the Omni in Atlanta, GA. That was about 18 months after I saw George Harrison's concert at the Omni. Wings Over America was incredible. The 'atmosphere' was provided by the fans, and appreciated by the fans and I have a feeling by the band as well.  I gave it 5 stars simply because it is available now in widescreen and Blu-ray with 5.1 sound. We in Las Vegas were not privileged enough to get the theatrical release.Initial reviews have stated that there is very little post production sweetening/enhancing of the music. A tweak here and there, but nothing to distract the listener from the purity of the concert.In the 70's Wings was an honest to goodness real Rock 'n Roll band. The '76 lineup was the best. It was made to tour and perform live. I can still remember the concert, the pyro of Live and Let Die, the hard rocking of the music. Real horns, honest to goodness real musicians playing real horns. My how times have changed.I had the shortened version of the concert on a VHS tape for about a decade. It was 'pleasant' but not very watchable on a standard CRT TV. Now with wide screen Blu-ray DVD to play on my Amazon purchased 55" Visio and a Sony Home Theater, it should be one fantastic trip back in time.I saw Paul in 1989 in LA and in 1993 in Las Vegas. Neither of those shows, which were great, could equal the majesty of WOA. A real band playing the (then) current hits and deep album tracks and a couple of 'oldies' for good measure.  Wings, Beatles and a Moody Blues for good measure all in one concert. Hard to beat that combo.Amazon, you have my order.Now Mr. McCartney and all, how about a little 'Let It Be' goodness on Blu-ray and DVD?? Isn't it about time to Live and Let Live on this one?

Tenth row, middle aisle and when he sang Let Me Roll It I had a chance to go to the front of the stage to take some pictures. Some outstanding moments in this film, just as I remembered. Soily was superior and you caught the excitement of the crowd in the film. It's great to see the band up on stage as they looked back in 1976. And you could so easily see how Paul was so happy to have Linda up there with him. She gamely did a great job of supporting her husband, as well. What a great show. I highly recommend this DVD.

reviewText: Paul McCartney is on stage with the love of his life and singing songs he wrote without having to share credit and let loose his own take on rock and roll at a time when some folks wondered if he was actually dead and this was an impostor or saw him as a weak and vain man failing to follow John's example of staying in expensive hotels and claiming poverty.  The most frustrating time in McCartney's life was also his happiest as he got to comment on phony Hair bands in their electric suits and conceited and self-appointed insiders like Madame Kitty as he powered through with sheer musical force.  He snarls and howls, laughs and giggles, bellows and bawls, fulfilling all of his Little Richard fantasies while reaffirming his genius in writing as well as performing.  You have to spend some time researching to get the context of this performance. Paul and Linda ,  Venus and Mars are all right tonight.

reviewText: As a neoBeatlemaniac who had all of their CDs by 1988 and all of the Beatles solo work (some 100 discs worth - even Ringo) by 1991, and of course the regrettable (in hindsight) Anthologies from 1995 to 1997, and even the Yellow Dog and Backtrack bootlegs, I can say with authority that this is worth getting for the audio quality and music content alone! Nevermind with the incredible Blu-ray quality video! Not previously available DVD or even VHS (possibly because they didn't have the audio quality of Betamax and Laserdisc), this sounds better than any album on your 10 speaker system - and the video quality is incredible. I feel as though I saw them live, and I only have a 46" TV. They have 30 awesome tracks (with Bluebird followed by Blackbird), and a perfect performance of Band on the Run - you must get this. Previously available in CD format as Wings Over America, it also comes in a great hardcover booklet format. Even the repeating menu track is great.
summary: Greatest McCartney Release Since Flowers In The Dirt (1989)

reviewText: I guess I got lucky. My copy of the Blu-Ray doesn't have any audio problems.(I played the DTS-MA surround audio, using an Oppo BDP-83 disc player, through an Integra DTC 9.9  A/V processor with an ADCOM power amp & a JBL "Studio Series" 5.1 speaker system). There were none of the low frequency drop-outs reported by other reviewers.As for the video quality, this filming is not up to modern standards. These concert performances(apparently taken from several shows) were filmed under low light conditions, yielding film footage that is, at best grainy, and at worst(during the acoustic performances) downright snowy. I viewed the Blu-Ray disc on a Panasonic 54" plasma T.V.The musical performances by Paul, Linda, Denny, Jimmy & Joe are superb, and this release has more songs than any previous release. This Blu-Ray disc has the complete set list for the tour. The audio has been newly remixed(at Abbey Road Studios) and this is a mixed blessing. The background vocals are often mixed down to be nearly inaudible.As for whether you should buy the Blu-Ray edition  or the DVD edition(if you are able to play both formats), the lower video resolution of the DVD might make the graininess of the film footage less apparent, but the Blu-Ray has the advantage of full fidelity, better than CD quality, uncompressed audio.

reviewText: I would have given it 4 and a half stars because I'm spoiled and expected a little more oomph picture wise for Blu-Ray, but the sound makes up for it. Besides, it wasn't shot with the idea of down the road hi-def. Actually I like the way it was shot, long before all the stupid fast cutting they do now. This is the closest you'll ever get to seeing the/a Beatle(s) concert we should have gotten, with them in their prime in the 70s, combined with advanced technology. That just wasn't to be, idiots.You only get 5 actual Beatle songs, but a lot of Paul's work with Wings in the early 70s has a decidedly Beatle feel to it. Songs like Let Me Roll It, Maybe I'm Amazed, and Let 'Em In easily fit the Beatles mold. This was 1976, only six years since the breakup, and three since the McCartney masterpiece Band on the Run. It's a great selection of songs, delivered by musicians having fun. A revelation is the diminutive guitarist Jimmy McCulloch, who is extremely talented, very young, and headed for a tragic ending.It's a very entertaining DVD, and quite charming for the 'cutting edge' technology of its day.
summary: Closest to the Beatles we'll ever see
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have been waiting for this for twenty-five years; an official release of Rockshow...  I will say that the the visuals are fantastic for what they had to work with; low concert lighting does not lend itself well to film and many times the film is overexposed in order to capture a acceptable image.  Rockshow is no exception and many scenes are quite grainy because of it.  However, my real contention with this BlueRay is with the DTS audio.  First of all, the alleged studio overdubbing of this soundtrack could not have lended itself to an easy remastering...  However,  the bass guitar (of all things) and kick drum seem to continuously wander in and out of the mix.  Background vocals most times are almost entirely inaudible.  On first listen I assumed that there was something wrong with my subwoofer but there isn't; it's the LFE channel on the DTS mix and because of it I consider this BlueRay to be defective.Bottom line...  The two channel mix on the bootleg DVD of this film is far superior to this surround one..I expect to be flamed for this review.Follow up...  I received my exchange copy today: No dice.  It's the same.  It will be going back and I will just take the refund, thank you very much.  Maybe in six months when they get their act together I'll try it again.  Another reviewer posted a sample that perfectly shows this defect...[...]*edit 07/20/2013..  I am reducing my review from a two star to a one star due to Amazon adding a disclaimer to the product description blaming the age of the film for the audio issues.  This film and in fact the entire tour was recorded with state of the art remote recording equipment.  It was recorded MUCH better than most music CDs today.  The audio problem is a phasing issue from the mastering process.  Shame on Amazon for continuing to sell a product that they know is defective.

reviewText: I am just glad to finally have this concert in my collection! I really miss Linda! Paul was fortunate to marry her & teach her the ropes in playing the best music! Critics hated her but as a musician, I can easily hear her talent & fatigue flaws! Everyone gets them in their early to middle stages of performing. The one thing I did notice tat the back-up singing was often way to low but Pauls was constantly at a hearable level! The back ups weren't as loud as on the c.d. I bought when it was first out. I've watched it twice in one week!! That's how good it was to have this disc with a nice tour fact filled booklet/dvd sleeve but it really would've really been nice to hear the back up singing like on the c.d tho! Really worth the money if you can deal with what I mentioned...I'm dealing with it! THANKS LINDA(it's dedicated to her & Jimmy McCartney) & Wings! UPDATE!!!!!!: I contacted Amazon.com about the audio issue and they exchanged the DVD for me & man...Maybe I'm Amazed!!!! The DVD was defective and now it sounds much better & fuller!! THANKS AMAZON! reviewText: Although I'm a diehard Beatles/Paul McCartney fan, I have never seen this film in its entirety (though I have the excerpts on the excellentThe McCartney YearsDVD set).  While I was unable to see ROCKSHOW in its limited big-screen showing in mid-May, I enjoyed the content of this new DVD release, but was disappointed in the sound quality (more on that below).This concert was filmed in 1976 at the Seattle Kingdome, a venue that was replaced several years ago on the same site by CenturyLink Field, the home of the NFL's Seattle Seahawks and Major League Soccer's Seattle Sounders FC.  MLB's Seattle Mariners, a former Kingdome tenant, play in Safeco Field, which is across the street from CenturyLink Field.  Macca will be playing at Safeco Field on his upcoming 2013 tour.This is the first time that the entire concert has been released on video.  A truncated version was released on Betamax in 1981, a year after the film was issued in theaters.  The truncated version was used for subsequent VHS and bootleg DVD reissues.  This is the film's first official release on DVD and Blu-ray.  The Wings lineup - Paul, Linda, Denny Laine, Joe English, and the late Jimmy McCulloch - is in top form through the show.  A bonus featurette, "A Very Lovely Party," is also included, with Hollywood after-concert party footage, which Ringo, Cher, and Elton John also attended, plus press-conference highlights and other tour footage.  The WINGS OVER THE WORLD documentary, featured on Disc 4 of theWings Over America Deluxe Edition, has much of the same concert footage as ROCKSHOW, but was not heavily remastered (no 5.1 surround sound). ROCKSHOW's picture quality is superb, but the sound quality leaves a lot to be desired, especially when compared to the highlights on THE MCCARTNEY YEARS.Eagle Rock Entertainment has packaged this set in a hardcover book, similar toThe Love We MakeandPaul McCartney: Live Kisses.  The booklet includes plenty of photos, the track listing, and technical information, and an essay by rock journalist and TV host Paul Gambaccini.For those who don't want to spend big money on the WOA Deluxe Edition, the purchase of this DVD, plus the Best Buy version of WOA with the bonus Cow Palace DVD (also found here), should be more than enough for all but the most die-hard McCartney fans.  And if WINGS OVER THE WORLD is ever issued as a standalone DVD, the only thing that fans will be missing are the Deluxe Edition's four books.Next to 2009'sGood Evening New York City, this is the best McCartney concert film.UPDATE:  After reading the comments of other reviewers on this site, I left a message on Eagle Rock Entertainment's Web site.  Now, after comparing this DVD to the highlights on THE MCCARTNEY YEARS, I know it is defective, so I took two stars off.  I'll try contacting Eagle Rock again, and as soon as they correct the problem, I will get a replacement.
summary: An excellent concert, but a defective DVD

reviewText: I had never seen this film before; it was very rare. Today (2013), it's a bit of a historical artifact. I have to admit, watching it was riveting.Technically, the DTS surround sound and the picture quality are both very, very good - especially for a 1976 film.Artistically, it made me realize that one of the toughest jobs in the world is to be an ex-Beatle. This guy has music coming out of his bones, so he has to keep doing it, even if his band breaks up. Hence Wings, who were very successful in the seventies. In fact, a majority of teenagers at the time thought that The Beatles were the band that Paul McCartney was in before Wings.The performances are very energetic, though Paul is stiff in the beginning as he tries to whoop up the band. Then two non-Paul Wings songs are performed, and though they're good, they don't hold a candle to his own compositions.Then, for the first time since the breakup, Paul does a handful of Beatle songs live. Unfortunately, the quality of those songs makes even the great Wings songs pale in comparison. Additionally, you find yourself comparing the musicians to the Beatles.Paul loosens up, though, and is obviously enjoying himself. It's hard not to get caught up in the vibe. And he's so young! Then there's more Wings songs, and you end up cutting him a lot of slack. After all, he's got the shadow of the Beatles hanging over his shoulder the whole time.This is a great disc, and worth adding to any Beatle freak's collection.One more surprise from actually watching Wings perform: I would have had Linda McCartney in my band any day. She does a damn fine job on backup vocals, and she's playing a multi-keyboard setup perfectly, nailing all the parts to the songs. I remember people dissing her at the time, but Paul was right and they were wrong. She was very talented.
Title: N/A

reviewText: EDIT 06/20: While I don't doubt that some people are experience audio problems with this release, I must point out that clearly not everyone is experiencing the bass drop-out problem. I, for one, did not - had I been anything less than satisfied with this, I would've been just as angry as anyone. Do a little research, read some forums on other sites concerning this disc, and see what is being said. I heard robust, full bass throughout while listening in 5.1 DTS-HD. The problem, whatever its cause, is clearly not being universally experienced. Think before click "not helpful" simply because a person had a good experience with Rockshow. (I received a review copy from the distributor, full release version, for the purposes of reviewing on a separate website - completely independent of Eagle Rock, I might add, and without compensation)The full 129 minute concert is a blast from start to finish. What a show, back when McCartney could build it around solo material almost exclusively and not disappoint anyone. I enjoy the non-McCartney tunes for the most part too - especially Denny's "Time to Hide" (always thought it was a highlight of Speed of Sound) and his revisiting of his Moody Blues classic "Go Now." So much energy on stage, with McCartney's voice sounding incredible on numbers like "Call Me Back Again" and "Beware My Love."Picture is framed at 1.78:1 - presumably representing (approximately) its theatrical aspect ratio. I think its a good transfer, but it must be pointed out that the footage is highly inconsistent. Close ups and medium shots generally fare best. the limitations of filming on 35mm in a dark, cavernous arena are all too apparent during softer focus (and grainy) shots.The 5.1 DTS-HD MA sounds terrific. It's not fancy (the rear speakers are generally just crowd noise/applause) but the instruments and vocals are punchy and clear (great way to take in McCartney's bass work, which really thumps).The only extra is a 10 minute montage (called "A Very Lovely Party") of home movie-type footage and some enthusiastic (and sometimes amusing) fan reaction footage. The time listed on the back of the package is 139 minutes because it includes this 10 minute piece (Eagle Rock does that with all their concert DVD/Blu-rays).Digibook package has a good new liner notes essay. The disc is slid into a cardboard pocket - which I hate because I don't like touching the disc surface and sliding it against cardboard every time I take it in or out. Relatively loose fitting at least.Can't recommend this more highly to see McCartney at his live performance peak.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The key word here is 'delightfully'. 'Dated' isn't necessarily a bad thing. Though I used to think much of Paul's post-Beatle body of work with Wings would never withstand the test of time, I found out something from this blu ray I wasn't seeing as well back then at the riverfront coliseum in Cincinnati during this tour; These weren't just nonsensical "silly love songs" and this wasn't just a "rockshow"; This was an event that really showcased an exceptional artist's (and his bandmember's) talents. This is a treasure trove of a rock legend 'doing his thing' in his own time... for all time.So through the grainy film of this blu ray I now see for the first time an extraordinary artist doing what he became famous for... blowing the top off the house. And you know what? Some of these songs from Paul's post-Beatles era as performed in this concert (such as Maybe I'm Amazed, Medicine Jar, Live and Let Die, Listen To What The Man Said, Beware My Love, and more) still hold up today, thanks to these great performances. I experienced no playback difficulty that other reviewers have mentioned (perhaps because I just uploaded a firmware update to my blu ray player), and the 5.1 sound is great. Be ready for a grainy picture though.
Title: N/A
